key_points: Facebook and its platforms, including Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger, experienced a global outage lasting close to six hours.
The outage was caused by a configuration change to the backbone routers that coordinate network traffic between Facebook's data centres.
Cloudflare provided a detailed explanation, mentioning the outage involved DNS and BGP which are crucial for internet connectivity.
All Facebook services were affected, including internal systems, leading to staff being locked out of offices and unable to use the internal communications platform.
The outage took a long time to fix due to the internal systems being down, making it hard for employees to diagnose and resolve the problem.
Facebook indicated the fix was slow due to the need to bring systems back to full capacity carefully.
A technical team had to manually reset servers in California where the problem originated.
Such outages, while uncommon, highlight the issues with a single point of failure for online services.
The outage happened during a tough time for Facebook, following paused plans for an Instagram for kids and whistleblower allegations.
The outage caused Facebook's share price to drop 4.9%, reducing CEO Mark Zuckerberg's personal wealth by $6bn.
